Congressional investigators say immigration and health officials were blindsided by the Trump administration's zero tolerance policy for migrants crossing the southwest border NPR's Joel Rose reports that's the finding of a report released today by the government Accountability Office
The jail report says officials at the departments of homeland security and health and Human Services did not plan for an increase in the number of children separated from their parents at the border
Officials at the age at an age age has told investigators they did not know in advance that attorney general Jeff Sessions plan to begin prosecuting everyone crossing the border illegally until he announced the policy publicly
At zero tolerance policy cost thousands of children to be separated from their parents more than twenty five hundred children ended up in government sponsored shelters before President Trump was forced to abandon the family separation policy under intense political pressure

Was chemical safety board says dust in factories poses a serious danger to workers as NPR's Rebecca Hersher reports dozens of people to die to dust explosions over the past decade this isn't normal household dust
It's dangerous best combustible dust like the tiny pieces of wood released by paper mills or the tiny particles that float away when you grind flower or corn meal at an industrial scale
If there's too much combustible dust in the air at a factory it can explode and that's a hazard for workers according to the chemical safety board fifty nine people have died in dust explosion since two thousand six
More than three hundred had been injured the explosions mostly happened in food processing and would in metal manufacturing facility is
